question: 4 (c)
sols_html:
Before we can calculate the integral, we use partial fraction.

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{x+7}{(x-3)(x+2)} &= \frac{A}{x-3} + \frac{B}{x+2}\\ &= \frac{A(x+2) + B(x-3)}{(x-3)(x+2)} = \frac{x\overbrace{(A+B)}^{= 1} + \overbrace{2A-3B}^{= 7}}{(x-3)(x+2)}\end{aligned}\]

So, we get two equations to solve for \(A\) and \(B\)

\[\begin{aligned} A+B&=1,\\ 2A-3B&=7\end{aligned}\]

and we get \(A=2, \ B=-1\).

So we find that

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{x+7}{(x-3)(x+2)}dx &= \int\left(\frac{2}{x-3} - \frac{1}{x+2}\right)\,dx \\ &= 2\ln(x-3) - \ln(x+2) + C\end{aligned}\]
